title: Research Associate
text:
Job Ref: 1491838 
An exciting opportunity has arisen to join our team in the Developmental Imaging and Biophysics Section at UCL Institute of Child Health (ICH) as a Research Associate. 
We are seeking a post-doctoral scientist with a PhD (or due to complete their PhD soon) in MRI physics or closely related area with strong academic and practical skills, looking to rapidly growing new fields of MR research. 
Post-mortem imaging has become an important new clinical service ( http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23683720 ). We are looking for someone to help build on and extend this program of research to apply quantitative MRI and spectroscopy to post-mortem imaging, to provide vitally needed non-invasive diagnostic biomarkers. The post holder will also help to support the development of rapid motion insensitive EEG-fMRI acquisitions to improve the pre-surgical evaluation of children with drug resistant focal epilepsy. 
This post is focussed on the development and application of new advanced MRI techniques and their translation into the clinical arena with a specific emphasis on 
The optimisation and development of quantitative MRI (i.e. multi parameter mapping of T1 / MT / T2* / PD / susceptibility mapping / diffusion) for post-mortem imaging (extending our existing program applying these methods in-vivo). 
The development of rapid motion insensitive EEG-fMRI acquisitions to improve the pre-surgical evaluation of children with drug resistant focal epilepsy 
This role benefits from the opportunity to see developments translated into clinical applications via our close links with the clinicians and patients at our partner Great Ormond Street Hospital, Europe’s largest paediatric hospital and with ICH Europe’s largest centre for paediatric research. 
The post holder will have access to excellent research facilities with a new Siemens Prisma (3T, 80mT/m gradients and 64 channel receive coil, multi-nuclear capability) and a Siemens Avanto MRI scanners with dedicated and funded research time. 
In addition we have a prospective motion correction camera ( www.kineticor.com ) that allows for real-time motion correction, an important aspect of this project. We also benefit from a wide range of MRI peripheral equipment including MRI compatible EEG/EMG/GSR/acceleration equipment and the support and technical input of brainproducts (GMBH, Gilching, Germany). 
This post is initially funded for 24 months. 
Performing analytical work in a highly numerate area of physics, medicine, computer science or allied field. 
It is also expected that the applicant will have additional experience in practical MRI physics, but applicants with a strong background in applied natural sciences, mathematics, computer science or related subject will also be considered. A strong ability for scientific computer programming is required e.g. in C++, Matlab or R. 
Applicants must have, or be close to obtaining, a PhD in MRI physics, multivariate analysis or be an exceptional natural scientist with a keen interest in this project (publishing their work in respected scientific journals). 
Applicants will be expected to have experience of preparing and publishing scientific articles in relevant journal, commensurate with level of experience.
